ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: We read a wonderful corpus of texts from must-read French authors, which allowed us to gain unique insights about a sociology topic from the perspective of literature.

In this course, we analyzed social mobility in different contexts and in different forms of media, whether it be non fiction or fiction, literature or film, etc. It was fascinating to compare these topics to discussions about race, sexuality, migration, and adoption as well. I also greatly appreciated how Mme Cadieu encouraged us to bring in our own expertise from our majors to better analyze this subject throughout this semester.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This was honestly the perfect class. Strengths include a great selection of texts, a manageable workload, an encouraging classroom environment, and the professor's expertise on the subject. The only weakness I can think of is that occasionally the connections between specific parts of the text and their meaning felt like a bit of a stretch, which made it harder to participate during those discussions.

Strengths: the professor! Prof. Cadieu is so knowledgeable and really wants everyone to engage with the material. Weakness: The books were all quite similar; the class would be improved with more variety.

This course has a variety of texts, many of which were created quite recently. This provided the class with very diverse examples of social mobility which we got to compare throughout the course. The assignments of the course were also very engaging, as the first essay was more creative and the second more traditional. I also appreciated the opportunity to present an expos on one of the texts, as I feel that this pushed me to improve my speaking in French.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! This is the best class I've taken at Yale. If you speak French well, are looking for a literature class, and are interested in social mobility journeys, you will very much enjoy this class. It was the only class I've ever taken where I actively wanted to do all the readings. Prof Cadieu is amazing; she's an expert on this subject matter and the perfect discussion leader in class. I cannot recommend this class enough. I was so sad when it ended. Please take it!

I would recommend this course to any student who enjoys more modern francophone literature and film. This course has a lot of auto-fiction in it, so it often concerns real-life struggles associated with social mobility. I think this course is especially interesting for students studying social sciences, as it is then possible to discuss social mobility and migration from a variety of viewpoints. It is a great course that I definitely recommend!
